I saw the photo first, me in a bloody wash of red with “RACIST” pulsing over my face. A couple of clicks brought me to this:

“In the darkest shadow of Bloomberg’s glossy office building in Manhattan, you may find a woman by the name of Dune Lawrence—a ‘journalist’ who has built a career on writing salacious articles about China.”

That was my introduction to TheBlot, a website I hope you’ve never heard of. The article went on and on: I’d been kicked out of China for poor job performance and eked out a living on minimum wage. My appearance was ravaged by “years of consuming hormone-packed fried chicken and stressing over money.” Now, I’d found a way to save my sinking career by writing negative articles about China and taking kickbacks from short sellers. In a cinematic scene set at Kentucky Fried Chicken, this Internet version of me laid out a strategy: “ ‘Bashing the Chinese could be a profitable niche for me,’ Lawrence said to a source while biting off a juicy chicken leg quarter at KFC. ‘The Chinese don’t vote, the Chinese don’t sue people, they just sit there taking the s---. How much better can it get? I am making a living out of it!’ ”

PM

Have a read

PM

This is becoming increasingly common for journalists

11:14 am

PM

Rio Tinto has announced Head of Copper Jean-Sebastian Jacques will succeed Sam Walsh as CEO from July. This raises
a small risk in our view given the market has grown to appreciate Sam's relentless FCF and cost discipline and the market
is less familiar with Jean-Sebastian compared to some of the other executives at the company. Nevertheless, this
addresses the succession issue that we raised through the recent results period (refer: RIO.L: Rio Tinto - The Succession
Question).

PM

1) In our view, investors might be slightly less familiar with Jean Sebastian who has been at the company for a handful of
years compared with greater familiarity with other possible succession candidates including Head of Iron Ore (who was
previously Head of Copper), the CFO and the head of Diamonds & Minerals.

11:15 am
PM

2) A CEO change won't be totally unexpected given Sam's initial 3 year contract and length of experience. Appointing an
executive in his mid-40s to lead the company may suggest we should expect a longer CEO tenure than his immediate
successor. continued in our note

PM

Investment case: We are Neutral rated on Rio Tinto recognising the recent strong run in iron ore prices is seasonal and
restocking related and we remain concerned about the medium to longer term trends in iron ore supply.
 Catalysts: Market will need to spend some time getting to know the new CEO in our view and this would be a key catalyst
for longer term investors in addition to iron ore prices, steel production and aluminium prices. Valuation: Trading 27x PE
(13x spot) and 8.4x EBITDA (5.8x spot) and a 2.4% 2017E div yield under our interpretation of the new 40-60% payout
ratio policy.

11:21 am

Aviate have been big on this

PM

The idea the sum of the parts is worth more than the current share price was resisted by Witty. He's now gone. Woodford and friends (including Och Ziff, ValueAct - who will probably get seat on board - and Sir Philip Hammond, get their way. The four FTSE companies in one (run poorly by Witty according to Woodford) can now be spun-off into separate, more focussed parts; HIV (ViiV), Consumer, Dermatology and new/leaner GSK (prescriptions drugs and vaccines). A dividend cut would be likely (which may scare a few) but reinvesting cash flow into a business generating double-digit returns is a more sensible allocation of resources, and will reward investors over the longer-term. Indeed, most we talk to would accept a dividend cut if it was accompanied by reform and investment in a pipeline of new drugs. Even Woodford is happy for such, and he runs an Income fund. While the Witty departure was well telegraphed and wont comes as much of a surprise (ref muted stock reaction) it does little to deter our conviction. However, change won’t happen overnight, indeed Witty may not go until next year, and so patience is required. Don't expect any fireworks in the short-term but patience will be rewarded. We remain a buyer, and would be adding to the position on any weakness.

PM

11:29 am
PM

It's still tough!

PM

We titled our year ahead report 'And you thought 2015 was tough!' on the basis that: i) stock market returns this year would be materially lower in 2016 than 2015 and ii) the consensus positions that allowed most investors to outperform last year were so broad and entrenched that there was a high risk of a contrarian rotation at some point.
Despite the decline seen in European equities year-to-date we remain relatively cautious as we feel that lower share prices are justified by a deterioration in the macro backdrop. Global growth expectations are being revised down (our economists have lowered their GDP forecasts today across all major regions) and the risk profile is rising. Against this backdrop MSCI Europe's N12M PE is unchanged since 1st January.

PM

He doesnt see a looming recession, but...

11:30 am
PM

We do not forecast a recession in our base case. Given this assumption it appears likely that investor concerns around economic growth did fall too far too fast at the beginning of the year as investors became more fearful of recession. In this regard, a run of less pessimistic data against the backdrop of bearish investor sentiment and positioning has driven the recent rebound in share prices. While this tactical bounce may last a little longer, particularly in light of the latest ECB policy initiatives, we believe that the medium-term outlook for stocks remains difficult and, as we explain later, our new 12m price target is 2% below current levels.

PM

Our cautious view reflects concerns around earnings, valuation and risk

PM

Our cautious view on European equities is predicated on three broad factors:

11:31 am
PM

i) While not forecasting an economic recession we do believe the macro backdrop for risk assets is becoming less conducive given the Fed is raising rates, confidence around other central banks actions are potentially waning and politics is becoming more complicated and populist. There are also a larger than usual number of risk events out there including China FX uncertainty, the US presidential election and Brexit.

PM

ii) We expect another year of negative EPS growth for MSCI Europe. Further afield, MSCI World's EPS has been falling for the last year and we now expect EPS contraction in 2016 across all major regions except the US.

PM

iii) We think absolute valuations trump relative valuations at this time given the tricky macro backdrop. Absolute valuations are currently around 15% above their long-run average.

11:01 am

Gate Ventures plc, an investment company focused on the media, entertainment, e-commerce, fashion retail, consultancy & operational projects, today announces that it has completed a £1 million investment in PlayJam, a technology company focussing on the distribution of interactive content. Gate's investment represents a 5% stake in PlayJam, which will increase to 8% based on certain criteria being met.

PM

Dr Johnny Hon, Chairman of Gate Ventures PLC, said: "The investment in PlayJam represents the continuation of the Company's investment in the high-tech media sector and diversification of Gate Ventures' expanding portfolio. We believe that our investment will give PlayJam the resources and knowhow to further expand into the Chinese high-growth home gaming and entertainment space. PlayJam's position in the high-tech media industry will complement Gate's other investee companies, allowing the Company to continue its progression as one of the leading entertainment and high-tech media organisations."

PM

Dr Johnny Hon began his career in private banking at ABN AMRO Bank in Hong Kong. Following this, he launched Global Group International Holdings Ltd in 1997. Global Group is now an international venture capital and angel investment company with interests ranging across a variety of business sectors including banking, property development, financial services, education, media, entertainment, gaming and telecoms.

Tony Shiret is selling Next

11:44 am
PM

!

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 6,610, down 110 (-1.64%), High: 6,770, Low: 6,575, Volume: 102.22k
PM

He's fallen out of love with the Directory business

11:45 am
PM

We cannot be completely certain that the 24 March Preliminary Results will see the denouement of Directory’s fall from grace. We have far too much regard for CEO Simon Wolfson’s strategic skills to expect him to take the recent problems without some meaningful response. But it does seem an appropriate time to pull together the arguments we have been making for nearly two years, when we first pointed out the signs that all was not well in this key value generator.

PM

Shiret now at Haitong, btw

PM

We have moved on from theorising about potential impacts arising from Next Directory’s reliance on consumer credit as the company itself has increasingly debated this area of its business model. Overall we feel that we are now at the end of a favourable period for the Directory and Next itself and that the company’s efforts to sustain this will make the reversion to a longer-term new trading pattern uncomfortable for investors, as the problems are more deep-rooted than a quarter or two of sales under-performance.

11:45 am
PM

The underlying issue seems to us to be erosion of the economics of the best customers – Directory’s Super Customers. The weakening of their performance is in our opinion likely to be reducing the NPV of the customer base overall. Currently this effect is not so apparent because the 40% reduction in new credit customer acquisition over the past four years is improving the profit balance within the whole business. But 15% new credit customer growth is extremely low by industry standards and will impact the Super Customer base progressively. Bad times are here for a while at Next Directory.

PM

In this note we have re-visited what we consider the relevant data and company disclosures on the Directory business in anticipation of the debate on this area next week.

Next Directory profit growth has gone from +95% for the four years ended Jan 2014 to +10% for the last two years.

UK Directory sales have increased by 8% and 4% (including Label) in 2014/15 and 2015/16E against growth in UK online clothing of 18% and 17%.

Next Directory credit customer gross recruitment has gone down from 700,000 four years ago to 400,000 this year a 40% drop.

Next has compensated for weakening underlying growth by increasing the range offered by 66% over the past two years with the introduction of New In/Collection and Label catalogues/collections. This is now fully annualised.

The growth in UK Directory customers of 6% in 2014/15 comprised +42% cash customers, -3% credit customers. We calculate that credit customers are worth around five times the annual contribution of cash customers.

APRs on the credit book have been reduced from 26% to 23% over the past 18 months. Next points to wanting to reduce it further for its best customers suggesting underlying profit performance issues with this historically important group.

PM

(History cheeckychappy:, History)

11:47 am
undefined
PM

One Savings Bank

PM

(Boncoeur -- gender issue)

11:48 am
PM

Top fo the 250 board this morning

OneSavings Bank PLC (OSB:LSE): Last: 286.46, up 32.26 (+12.69%), High: 292.80, Low: 263.00, Volume: 2.03m
PM

rocket

11:49 am
PM

Year end figs well ahead of expectations

PM

Which is welcome news for Trader Gordon, for one

PM

Ian at Investec

11:50 am
PM

We see OSB as a reassuringly predictable story which delivers extraordinary returns on a consistent basis. As such, it is something of a mystery to us as to why analysts/investors have been so fickle; the stock fell c.40% in 4 months ahead of today’s numbers! H2 2015 Reported EPS of 19.1p is 1% below our “top-of-range” forecast (19.36p) but 22% ahead of Bloomberg consensus (15.7p). The FY15 u/l RoE is 32% with a cost:income ratio of just 26%. Trading on 5.5x 2017e EPS, we expect this stock to fly today! BUY.

PM

22% beat -- impressive

PM

Before today, our H2 2015 EPS forecast of 19.36p was 24% ahead of Bloomberg consensus (15.7p). Perhaps more importantly, our existing forecasts of 39.8p in 2016e and 45.9p in 2017e are ahead by 13% and 8%; we think today’s results should drive material consensus upgrades.
Further net loan growth of £0.2bn in Q4 2015 takes the total to £1.2bn (+31%) for FY15, a notable step-up from £0.9bn (+29%) in 2014. We currently model slightly “slower” growth in 2016e – a mere £1.1bn (+22%)!
As guided, NIM continued to improve; up 18bps YoY to 3.09% in 2015 as OSB manages record demand for buy-to-let mortgages through price. Investors really should not confuse the professional buy-to-let market with the “dinner party landlord” segment where the supply and demand pricing dynamics are entirely different. Unsurprisingly, OSB enters 2016 with a record pipeline.
The CET1 capital ratio has strengthened by 60bps HoH in H2 2015 to 11.6% and the FY15 dividend is 8.7p (vs consensus 8.0p, us 8.5p); a yield of 3.4%.
As a reminder, we continue to believe that Aldermore (Buy) – our top pick – offers a more transparent, defensive and diversified story which, on a 12 month view is likely to deliver material outperformance against every UK bank in our coverage. However, OneSavings has now displaced it as the “cheapest”, trading on just 7.5x 2015e EPS, or, perhaps more remarkably, just 5.5x 2017e.
Buy rec and 380p target price reaffirmed. Detailed forecasts under review.

11:51 am
PM

Metro Bank PLC (MTRO:LSE): Last: 2,008, up 8 (+0.40%), Volume: 3.76k
PM

11:54 am
PM

Sirius Minerals

PM

Here's some Shore

PM

SIRIUS MINERALS^ (SXX, BUY, Current Price 22.75p) – Positive DFS results, essentially in-line with our estimates; we reiterate BUY stance. The eagerly-awaited results from the Definitive Feasibility Study (DFS) on Sirius’s wholly-owned York project were positive, in our view. Most of the key numbers were essentially in-line with our expectations as set out in our Initiation of Coverage note (‘Brightest star in the junior potash universe’; published on 14th September 2015).

11:55 am
PM

Production profile and timelines essentially in-line with our modelling: The DFS envisages Phase 1 and 2 capacities of 10Mtpa and 20Mtpa, respectively with first production occurring c.2021, reaching 10Mtpa in 2024 and achieving 20Mtpa in 2028. Mine life was nominally 50 years but Sirius noted (as had we) that this could potentially be

100 years.

· Opex numbers lower than our estimates: Average operating cost at 20Mtpa was estimated at US$27.2/t, which compares favourably with our US$33/t. We had assumed a fixed cost percentage of 33%, whereas the DFS had this at 16% and 9% for Phases 1 and 2 – the lower numbers are of particular (positive) significance for periods in which the mine is operating at below installed capacity, improving project resilience.

· Phase 1 capex and peak funding essentially in-line: The capital funding requirement to positive net cash flow (as opposed to ‘actual capex’) was estimated by the DFS at US$3.565bn (albeit including US$0.445bn for contingencies), slightly higher than the US$3.364bn suggested by our modelling. Capex for the mine, mineral transport system (MTS), materials handling facility (MHF), port and infrastructure amounted to US$2.69bn, versus our estimate of US$2.97bn.

· Phase 2 capex appears significantly higher – but we allocated much more to sustaining capex: The DFS projected US$0.367bn during the ramp-up to 13Mtpa and a further US$1.175bn to 20Mtpa. At first glance, this is significantly higher than the US$647m we had allowed, but we believe this is because we had allocated more to sustaining capital (US$86.8m/year, versus the DFS’ US$30m/year). Indeed, we note that adding the PV of the sustaining capex difference (c.US$0.5bn) to the our Phase 2 capex results in a very similar overall number (US$1.15bn).

· Impressive NPV and IRR; in-line on comparable basis: Based on the above, the DFS derived impressive nominal post-tax NPV10% and IRR figures at construction start of US$15.1bn and 25.7%, respectively. These assumed average polyhalite prices of US$166/t and US$186/t for the first 10 years and over the average mine life, respectively, and annual inflation of 2% on prices and costs. The DFS NPV is therefore not directly comparable with that from our real model, which assumed a flat polyhalite price of US$150/t. Substituting the DFS production profile and cost estimates into our Initiation model, we obtained a project NPV10% of £3.16bn, essentially in-line with our £3.09bn.

PM

Again in-line with our expectations, Sirius is now planning to raise c.US$3.5bn in total (our estimate: US$3.55bn). The two-stage plan is maintained, but the Stage 1 proportion has increased to c.46% (or US$1.6bn; previously: c.33%) due to the inclusion of a proportion of indirect costs, project management and owner’s cost and contingencies. According to the company, discussions have been underway “for a significant period of time” with potential providers of structured debt and equity for Stage 1. Sirius now intends to “engage in a more detailed formal due diligence process” with key parties with a view to obtaining binding commitments “as quickly as possible”.

In the meantime, we note that Sirius remains very well-funded for a company at this stage, with £25m of cash on its balance sheet as of February 2016. While an investment in Sirius will become progressively derisked as the company advances towards production, we believe that it already offers a more robust, lower-risk investment with the prospect of better returns than typical of its peers. We temporarily suspend our Risked NPV estimate while we overhaul our Sirius model, but we have no qualms in reiterating our BUY recommendation.

Sirius Minerals PLC (SXX:LSE): Last: 18.17, down 4.58 (-20.13%), High: 23.75, Low: 16.50, Volume: 53.96m
11:55 am
PM

Sheesh

PM

Liberum also on the wrong side of this one

PM

Sirius has released its Definitive Feasibility Study, highlighting marginally
higher capex but lower opex estimates than we had forecast and delivering
robust economics. Capex is expected at $3.6bn for the first 10mt vs. our
$3.3bn estimate (for 13mt), whilst opex of $33/t compares to our $38/t
forecast. Applying Sirius pricing methodology the project delivers a $15bn
NPV vs. our previous $4.6bn estimate. The key difference in our valuations
remains pricing assumptions; we assume prices are set by production
costs at the marginal producer, rather than nutrient value. Management
focus will now turn to delivering the significant debt and equity funding
package of $1.6bn for the first phase.

11:57 am
PM

Some weird mismatches here on valuations

PM

The critical difference between Sirius's project NPV of $15bn and ours of $4.6bn lies in polyhalite
pricing assumptions. Sirius expects a real average polyhalite price of $166/T for the first 10 years of
operation. This price is linked to the current pricing formula on 3.6mt of offtake. Sirius then expects
prices to rise, generating an average mine-life equivalent price of $186/T as initial offtake agreements
unwind and allow polyhalite prices to rise towards nutrient value (of c.$300/T).
Our assumptions have been more conservative taking the view that production costs, not nutrient
value, would be the key driver of prices. Our initial pricing assumption of $150/T is not dissimilar to
that of Sirius and is also based on current pricing formulae in Sirius's offtake agreements. However,
once Sirius exceeds c.4mT production, we assume that polyhalite starts competing more aggressively
with SOP, today’s main source of chloride-free potassium. Today’s SOP market is supply-constrained
and so it is plausible that polyhalite could expand demand without a competitive response but a more
conservative assumption is to assume that polyhalite prices fall to c.$125/T, which we set as just
below the top of the SOP cost curve.

PM

Richard KNights the analyst there

PM

PM

Phew - thanks to big position on magnificent SPRINTER SACRE and a small one on the bumper winner (!) managed to finish ahead yesterday. Paddy’s Day today - though not sure it’s influenced my picks.
Three handicaps today,

PM

This is the Shrewdette

12:01 pm
PM

1:30 JLT Novice Chase. With the fav here GARDE LE VICTOIRE won his last 3 including here, 4/1 still generally available.

2:10 Pertemps Final Handicap Hurdle. 24 mines here! Should ensure wiping out most of the Scoop6.
But help at hand - most firms paying 5 places do tiny EWs. ARPEGE D’ALENE 16/1, CUP FINAL 10/1, and the mare BROXBOURNE 25/1.

2:50 Ryanair Chase. If there’s any justice fav Vautour will get turned over (cos of Ricci/Mullins f****** the ante-post market) and victory will be for sponsor O’Leary’s ROAD TO RICHES 7/1 W, and also have AL FEROF 14/1 EW.

PM

3:50 Ryanair World Hurdle.
I’ve long-held ante-post on THISTLECRACK at slightly better odds than now 5/4 W - 3-3 this season he will be hard to pass. Though last year’s winner COLE HARDEN 7/1 EW will make him work for it.

4:10 Handicap Chase - 22 runner minefield. Bet365 & SkyBet paying 5 places so … FINGAL BAY 10/1 EW ran well all top handicaps; NICEONEFRANKIE 20/1 lightly races, last won in 2014 at this track, and JOHNS SPIRIT who has slipped to a lowly mark 13/2. Tiny Each ways all round.

4:50 Mares Novice Hurdle - a new race this year.
